ratings.comment: She is awful.  She is very rude and disrespectful at times.   When students ask questions, she usually tells the student they should know that or you will have to look that up.  Her test are extremely hard.  I took calculus 221 at UW-Green Bay and got an A.  I retook it at UW-Madison because I wanted to be sure I knew the material, I got a C.

Did not know what she was doing the entire semester. Very inconsistent in grading and didn't allow for regrades even when it was obvious the grading was incorrect. She instead accused me of cheating. Very inappropriate for an instructor to do. Quizzes tend to be more questions than exams. Very difficult to finish in time given.

The lectures are taught clearly and the homework clearly reflects the lectures. She also gives time to ask homework questions where she gives tips on starting proofs. However, the exams are NOT easy with all three averages in the 60's this semester. Study all the material well and memorize how to do all proofs for the exams.

She's a pretty strict grader on tests and homework assignments were thorough to say the least. Her lectures are beautifully organized, but she moves through material so quickly you often miss out on explanations. Tests were incredibly straight forward, with questions always coming from homework (which she reviews during class) or lecture examples.

At first Dr. Offerman's introverted nature makes her seem hard to approach.  However, once you get through that serious facade she is a kind and caring lady.  She is not really clear when it comes to describing her lessons and her lectures are very complex with not a lot of time to digest the information. Go to her office hours!

Most of class time is extensive note taking and examples.  NOT a lot of time taken to explain things, major concepts and their relevance to the chapter .   I dropped into my friends' 221 (non-offerman) lecture to check it out, and I was not overwhelmed by examples  because the teacher paused to reinforce concepts. I learned so much more. Good luck.
Hard tests and quizzes.

She can be very unclear when you ask a question in class, but she is much better in office hours. She is very nice and helpful, but in class she doesn't have time to answer every little question. No discussion section. Tests are very fair, quizzes are difficult, group projects are annoying, and the book is useless. I would recommend her.
Explains material very well. If you ask a question, be prepared for her to make you feel stupid for doing so.

Offerman would give us a lecture everyday and made us feel dumb if we didn't understand her methods. Tests were tough although the first final given was very fair. She doesn't answer questions very well in class, office hours were alittle more helpful. I think deep down she is brillant however she can't teach very well.

Offerman was a MUCH better prof by the end of the year. The format of quizzes are tough, conceptual, and long, but exams are reasonable. Study for the exams, and they are not a problem! The book is pretty much useless. All homework is online and completion, so easy points! Office hours will save your life; go regularly. Recommend for Calculus!

This is her first time teaching and you could really tell. She looks at the board and writes for the whole class, each and every day. The test are tricky with little correlation to the homework. Plus her idea of a quiz is 100+ points that very few people will finish.
This is her first time teaching and you could really tell. She looks at the board and writes for the whole class, each and every day. The test are tricky with little correlation to the homework.
Offerman's teaching style is extremely wordy and full of definitions. The "book" didn't help too much and I had to use YouTube and different calc websites to learn the material.

Ok so literally everyone is hating on Christine on here and they are exaggerating how poor she is. This was (2014 fall) her first semester teaching ever and as far as those go, this one was far from a disaster.  By the end of the year Christine was a completely different prof than at the beginning. Christine has the potential to be a great prof.

She is a great professor! Much better than other calculus teachers at Madison. Ignore the bad reviews on here, she is not that bad! I promise! Calculus is just a hard subject in general and it does take work to master it. Offerman is always available to answer your questions at office hours and is very passionate about math.

Rough around the edges at first, but if you commit yourself to going to office hours, she completely explained everything and was very patient. This is a 200 calc class, not simple algebra. There isn't an easy calc class. Homework is graded on completion,  and super helpful. This was her first semester teaching ever, and she will only get better.

Probably THE hardest class I have ever taken. I took University level math classes before and would get a high B to A. In this glass I'm literally getting an F. So hard! I would not take this professor. Yes she is very nice. And yes she knows what she's talking about. But, she is very wordy and doesn't know how to answer question....

A lot of work is required for a good grade.  Her lectures are VERY comprehensive and organized, but she is not very helpful if you ask her a question directly. However,  if you go to the lectures, do the homework, and get help when needed, there are no surprises on the exams. Would recommend if you are willing to put in a lot of outside effort.

Stares at the board and mumbles through lecture. Not helpful at all, and dances around questions. If she does answer a question she will tell you to read the textbook, which also does not help. AVOID AT ALL COSTS!

Dances around questions, lectures are long and will just make you more confused about the material being taught. Not helpful, can tell its her first year teaching the class here. Got the homework, and most of the problem session problems right, failed both midterms. If you didnt take AP CALC last year, good luck with getting a B or better.

It is her first time teaching, and you can tell. She is young and inexperienced which could be why it is so hard for her to convey her thoughts to the class. Took Calc in High School and did well on the AP test, this is just a lot and very quickly with no help and no discussion sections. Really hard.

Offerman considers getting 40%'s quizzes to be "good" and "normal" and she just dances around questions when you ask her for help. Her notes are purely definitions and are far to wordy which makes learning the material confusing. I've basically had to teach myself everything via khan academy and youtube. Find someone who is at least experienced.

Honestly one of the hardest classes I've ever taken. You have to do all of the homework, for sure. No textbook what so ever, and the discussion sections were basically non-existent. Basically have to teach yourself things from your notes after class. If you ask for help, she basically just looks at you and tells you to look at the problem different
